ACT
106
Presumptions of validity of assignment and distribution
Assignment and distribution of property are valid only if all the children and other descendants of the assignor , who are called to inherit it by law, have agreed to it.
The contract on assignment and distribution of property is valid only if it is drawn up in writing and:
- certified by a judge of the competent court, or
- drawn up in the form of a notarial deed, or
- confirmed ( solemnized ) by a notary public.
The authorized persons referred to in paragraph 2 of this article are obliged to read the contract and warn the contracting parties about the consequences of the contract.
A descendant who did not give consent may give it later, in the form referred to in paragraph 2 of this article.
Assignment and distribution remain valid if the descendant who did not agree died before the testator and left no descendants, or renounced the inheritance, or is excluded from the inheritance, or is unworthy.
